|He was waiting to choke you on a marble, to smother you with a dry-cleaning bag, to sizzle you into eternity with a fast and lethal boogie of electricity- Available At Your Nearest Switch plate Or Vacant Light Socket Right Now. There was death in a quarter bag of peanuts, an aspirated piece of steak, the next pack of cigarettes. He was around all the time, he monitored all the checkpoints between the mortal and the eternal. Dirty needles, poison beetles, downed live wires, forest fires. Whirling roller skates that shot nerdy little kids into busy intersections. When you got into the bathtub to take a shower, Oz got right in there too- Shower With A Friend. When you got on an airplane, Oz took your boarding pass. He was in the water you drank, the food you ate. Who's out there? you howled in the dark when you were all frightened and all alone, and it was his answer that came back: Don't be afraid, it's just me. Hi, howaya? You got cancer of the bowel, what a bummer, so solly, Cholly! Septicemia! Leukemia! Atherosclerosis! Coronary thrombosis! Encephalitis! Osteomyelitis! Hey-ho, let's go! Junkie in a doorway with a knife. Phone call in the middle of the night. Blood cooking in battery acid on some exit ramp in North Carolina. Big handfuls of pills, munch em up. That peculiar cast of the fingernails following asphyxiation- in its final grim struggle to survive the brain takes all oxygen that is left, even that in those living cells under the nails. Hi, folks, my name's Oz the Gweat and Tewwible, but you can call me Oz if you want- hell, we're old friends by now. Just stopped by to whop you with a little congestive heart failure or a cranial blood clot or something; can't stay, got to see a woman about a breech birth, then I've got a little smoke-inhalation job to do in Omaha.|,Stephen King, 
|It's probably wrong to believe there can be any limit to the horror which the human mind can experience. On the contrary, it seems that some exponential effect begins to obtain as deeper and deeper darkness falls - as little as one may like to support the idea that when the nightmare grows black enough, horror spawns horror, one coincidental evil begets other, often more deliberate evils, until finally blackness seems to cover everything. And the most terrifying question of all may be just how much horror the human mind can stand and still maintain a wakeful, staring, unrelenting sanity. That such events have their own Rube Goldberg absurdity goes almost without saying. At some point, it all starts to become rather funny. That may be the point at which sanity begins either to save itself or to buckle and break down; that point at which one's sense of humor begins to reassert itself.|,Stephen King,

|Something inhuman has come to Tarker's Mills, as unseen as the full moon riding the night sky high above. It is the Werewolf, and there is no more reason for its coming now than there would be for the arrival of cancer, or a psychotic with murder on his mind, or a killer tornado. Its time is now, its place is here, in this little Maine town where baked bean church suppers are a weekly event, where small boys and girls still bring apples to their teachers, where the Nature Outings of the Senior Citizen's Club are religiously reported in the weekly paper. Next week there will be news of a darker variety.Outside, its tracks begin to fill up with snow, and the shriek of the wind seems savage with pleasure. There is nothing of God or Light in that heartless sound—it is all black winter and dark ice.The cycle of the Werewolf has begun.|,Stephen King,January

Not all boats which sail away into darkness never find the sun again, or the hand of another child; if life teaches anything at all, it teaches that there are so many happy endings that the man who believes there is no God needs his rationality called into serious question...So drive away quick, drive away while the last of the light slips away...drive away from Derry, from memory...but not from desire. That stays, the bright cameo of all we were and all we believed as children, all that shone in our eyes even when we were lost and the wind blew in the night. Drive away and try to keep smiling. content: |To hold the same views at forty as we held at twenty is to have been stupefied for a score of years

content: |The true wisdom is to be always seasonable

content: |All error
name: not merely verbal
extra: is a strong way of stating that the current truth is incomplete. The follies of youth have a basis in sound reason
column4: just as much as the embarrassing questions put by babes and sucklings. Their most antisocial acts indicate the defects of our society. When the torrent sweeps the man against a boulder
column5: you must expect him to scream
column6: and you need not be surprised if the scream is sometimes a theory. Shelley
column7: chafing at the Church of England
column8: discovered the cure of all evils in universal atheism. Generous lads irritated at the injustices of society
column9: see nothing for it but the abolishment of everything and Kingdom Come of anarchy. Shelley was a young fool; so are these cocksparrow revolutionaries. But it is better to be a fool than to be dead. It is better to emit a scream in the shape of a theory than to be entirely insensible to the jars and incongruities of life and take everything as it comes in a forlorn stupidity. Some people swallow the universe like a pill; they travel on through the world
column10: like smiling images pushed from behind. For God’s sake give me the young man who has brains enough to make a fool of himself! As for the others
column11: the irony of facts shall take it out of their hands
column12: and make fools of them in downright earnest
column13: ere the farce be over. There shall be such a mopping and a mowing at the last day
column14: and such blushing and confusion of countenance for all those who have been wise in their own esteem
column15: and have not learnt the rough lessons that youth hands on to age. If we are indeed here to perfect and complete our own natures
column18: and more sympathetic against some nobler career in the future
column19: we had all best bestir ourselves to the utmost while we have the time. To equip a dull
column20: respectable person with wings would be but to make a parody of an angel.|

content: |I suppose it is written that any one who sets up for a bit of a philosopher
name: must contradict himself to his very face. For here have I fairly talked myself into thinking that we have the whole thing before us at last; that there is no answer to the mystery
extra: except that there are as many as you please; that there is no centre to the maze because
column5: its centre is everywhere; and that agreeing to differ with every ceremony of politeness
column6: is the only “one undisturbed song of pure concent” to which we are ever likely to lend our musical voices.|

content: |There is a sort of dead-alive
name: hackneyed people about
extra: who are scarcely conscious of living except in the exercise of some conventional occupation. … They have no curiosity; they cannot give themselves over to random provocations; they do not take pleasure in the exercise of their faculties for its own sake; and unless necessity lays about them with a stick
column4: they will even stand still. It is no good speaking to such folk: they cannot be idle

content: |It is a sore thing to have laboured along and scaled the arduous hilltops
name: and when all is done
extra: find humanity indifferent to your achievement. Hence physicists condemn the unphysical; financiers have only a superficial toleration for those who know little of stocks; literary persons despise the unlettered; and people of all pursuits combine to disparage those who have none.But though this is one difficulty of the subject
column4: it is not the greatest. You could not be put in prison for speaking against industry
column5: but you can be sent to Coventry for speaking like a fool. The greatest difficulty with most subjects is to do them well; therefore
column6: please to remember this is an apology. It is certain that much may be judiciously argued in favour of diligence; only there is something to be said against it

content: |The observer (poor soul
name: with his documents!) is all abroad. For to look at the man is but to court deception. We shall see the trunk from which he draws his nourishment; but he himself is above and abroad in the green dome of foliage
extra: hummed through by winds and nested in by nightingales. And the true realism were that of the poets
column4: to climb up after him like a squirrel

content: |To be honest
name: to be kind — to earn a little and to spend a little less
extra: to make upon the whole a family happier for his presence
column4: to renounce when that shall be necessary and not be embittered
column6: but these without capitulation — above all
column8: to keep friends with himself — here is a task for all that a man has of fortitude and delicacy. He has an ambitious soul who would ask more; he has a hopeful spirit who should look in such an enterprise to be successful. There is indeed one element in human destiny that not blindness itself can controvert: whatever else we are intended to do
column9: we are not intended to succeed; failure is the fate allotted.|

It is not only the mischief of diseases, and villany of poisons, that make an end of us: we vainly accuse the fury of guns, and the new inventions of death; it is in the power of every hand to destroy us, and we are beholden unto every one we meet he doth not kill us. There is, therefore, but one comfort left, that though it be in the power of the weakest arm to take away life, it is not in the strongest to deprive us of death: God would not exempt himself from that, the misery of immortality in the flesh; he undertook not that was immortal. Certainly there is no happiness within this circle of flesh, nor is it in the optics of those eyes to behold felicity; the first day of our jubilee is death. The devil hath therefore failed of his desires: we are happier with death, than we should have been without it. There is no misery but in himself, where there is no end of misery; and so, indeed, in his own sense, the stoic is in the right. He forgets that he can die who complains of misery. We are in the power of no calamity while death is in our own.|,Thomas Browne,Section 44
|Now, besides the literal and positive kind of death, there are others whereof divines make mention, and those, I think not merely metaphorical, as mortification, dying unto sin and the world. Therefore, I say, every man hath a double horoscope, one of his humanity, his birth; another of his Christianity, his baptism, and from this do I compute or calculate my nativity, — not reckoning those Horæ combustæ and odd days, or esteeming myself anything, before I was my Savior's, and enrolled in the register of Christ. Whosoever enjoys not this life, I count him but an apparition, though he wear about him the sensible affections of flesh. In these moral acceptions, the way to be immortal is to die daily; nor can I think I have the true theory of death, when I contemplate a skull, or behold a skeleton with those vulgar imaginations it casts upon us.|,Thomas Browne,Section 45

|To be nameless in worthy deeds exceeds an infamous history. The Canaanitish woman lives more happily without a name, than Herodias with one. And who had not rather have been the good thief, than Pilate?But the iniquity of oblivion blindly scattereth her poppy, and deals with the memory of men without distinction to merit of perpetuity. Who can but pity the founder of the Pyramids? Herostratus lives that burnt the Temple of Diana, he is almost lost that built it.|,Thomas Browne,Chapter V
|In vain we compute our felicities by the advantage of our good names, since bad have equal durations, and Thersites is like to live as long as Agamemnon. Who knows whether the best of men be known, or whether there be not more remarkable persons forgot, than any that stand remembered in the known account of time? Without the favour of the everlasting register, the first man had been as unknown as the last, and Methuselah's long life had been his only chronicle.Oblivion is not to be hired. The greater part must be content to be as though they had not been, to be found in the register of God, not in the record of man. Twenty seven names make up the first story before the flood, and the recorded names ever since contain not one living century. The number of the dead long exceedeth all that shall live. The night of time far surpasseth the day, and who knows when was the Æquinox? Every hour adds unto that current arithmetick, which scarce stands one moment.|,Thomas Browne,Chapter V

content: It's important to remember that the relationship between different media tends to be complementary. When new media arrive they don't necessarily replace or eradicate previous types. Though we should perhaps observe a half second silence for the eight-track. — There that's done. What usually happens is that older media have to shuffle about a bit to make space for the new one and its particular advantages. Radio did not kill books and television did not kill radio or movies — what television did kill was cinema newsreel. TV does it much better because it can deliver it instantly. Who wants last week's news?
name: Douglas Adams

|Property must be secured, or liberty cannot exist. But if unlimited or unbalanced power of disposing property, be put into the hands of those who have no property, France will find, as we have found, the lamb committed to the custody of the wolf. In such a case, all the pathetic exhortations and addresses of the national assembly to the people, to respect property, will be regarded no more than the warbles of the songsters of the forest. The great art of law-giving consists in balancing the poor against the rich in the legislature, and in constituting the legislative a perfect balance against the executive power, at the same time that no individual or party can become its rival. The essence of a free government consists in an effectual control of rivalries. The executive and the legislative powers are natural rivals; and if each has not an effectual control over the other, the weaker will ever be the lamb in the paws of the wolf. The nation which will not adopt an equilibrium of power must adopt a despotism. There is no other alternative. These two tyrants are fashion and party. They are sometimes at variance, and I know not whether their mutual hostility is not the only security of human happiness. But they are forever struggling for an alliance with each other; and, when they are united, truth, reason, honor, justice, gratitude, and humanity itself in combination are no match for the coalition. Upon the maturest reflection of a long experience, I am much inclined to believe that fashion is the worst of all tyrants, because he is the original source, cause, preserver, and supporter of all others.|,John Adams, 
|Liberty, according to my metaphysics, is an intellectual quality; an attribute that belongs not to fate nor chance. Neither possesses it, neither is capable of it. There is nothing moral or immoral in the idea of it. The definition of it is a self-determining power in an intellectual agent. It implies thought and choice and power; it can elect between objects, indifferent in point of morality, neither morally good nor morally evil. If the substance in which this quality, attribute, adjective, call it what you will, exists, has a moral sense, a conscience, a moral faculty; if it can distinguish between moral good and moral evil, and has power to choose the former and refuse the latter, it can, if it will, choose the evil and reject the good, as we see in experience it very often does.|,John Adams,|I, p. 448|
|I do not say that democracy has been more pernicious on the whole, and in the long run, than monarchy or aristocracy. Democracy has never been and never can be so durable as aristocracy or monarchy; but while it lasts, it is more bloody than either.|,John Adams,|XVIII, p. 483. Usually misquoted as Democracy…while it lasts is more bloody than either aristocracy or monarchy".|

content: |It is easier to love humanity as a whole than to love one's neighbor. There may even be a certain antagonism between love of humanity and love of neighbor; a low capacity for getting along with those near us often goes hand in hand with a high receptivity to the idea of the brotherhood of men. About a hundred years ago a Russian landowner by the name of Petrashevsky recorded a remarkable conclusion: "Finding nothing worthy of my attachment either among women or among men
name: I have vowed myself to the service of mankind." He became a follower of Fourier
extra: and installed a phalanstery on his estate. The end of the experiment was sad
column4: but what one might perhaps have expected: the peasants — Petrashevsky's neighbors-burned the phalanstery.Some of the worst tyrannies of our day genuinely are "vowed" to the service of mankind
column5: yet can function only by pitting neighbor against neighbor. The all-seeing eye of a totalitarian regime is usually the watchful eye of the next-door neighbor. In a Communist state love of neighbor may be classed as counter-revolutionary.|

content: |In exceptional cases

column5: the present dominant role of the intellectual in the modernization of backward countries also militates against the prevalence of individual freedom. Not only does the intellectual's penchant for tutoring
column7: and regulating promote a regimented social pattern
column8: but his craving for the momentous is bound to foster an austere seriousness inhospitable to the full play of freedom. The intellectual "transforms the prosaic achievements of society into Promethean tasks
column10: tragic epics." The strained atmosphere of an eternal drama working up toward a climax and a crisis is optimal for heroes and saints but not for the autonomous individual shaping his life to the best of his ability. The chances are that should an advanced country come into the keeping of the intellectual it would begin to show many of the hectic traits which seem to us characteristic of a backward country in the throes of awakening.|
column12: |Ch. 12: "Concerning Individual Freedom" [In this passage "transforms the prosaic achievements of society into Promethean tasks
column14: tragic epics" is a quotation of Raymond Aron from The Opium of the Intellectuals (1957)

content: |To the intellectual the struggle for freedom is more vital than the actuality of a free society. He would rather "work
name: fight
column4: for liberty than have it." The fact is that up to now the free society has not been good for the intellectual. It has neither accorded him a superior status to sustain his confidence nor made it easy for him to acquire an unquestioned sense of social usefulness. For he derives his sense of usefulness mainly from directing
column6: and planning — from minding other people's business — and is bound to feel superfluous and neglected where people believe themselves competent to manage individual and communal affairs
column7: and are impatient of supervision and regulation. A free society is as much a threat to the intellectual's sense of worth as an automated economy is to the workingman's sense of worth. Any social order that can function with a minimum of leadership will be anathema to the intellectual.The intellectual craves a social order in which uncommon people perform uncommon tasks every day. He wants a society throbbing with dedication
column9: and worship. He sees it as scandalous that the discoveries of science and the feats of heroes should have as their denouement the comfort and affluence of common folk. A social order run by and for the people is to him a mindless organism motivated by sheer physiologism.|
column14: for liberty than have it" is a quotation of Lincoln Steffens from The Autobiography of Lincoln Steffens (1931)

content: |The explosive component in the contemporary scene is not the clamor of the masses but the self-righteous claims of a multitude of graduates from schools and universities. This army of scribes is clamoring for a society in which planning
name: regulation
extra: and supervision are paramount and the prerogative of the educated. They hanker for the scribe's golden age
column4: for a return to something like the scribe-dominated societies of ancient Egypt
column6: and Europe of the Middle Ages. There is little doubt that the present trend in the new and renovated countries toward social regimentation stems partly from the need to create adequate employment for a large number of scribes. And since the tempo of the production of the literate is continually increasing
column7: the prospect is of ever-swelling bureaucracies.|

content: |It has been often stated that a social order is likely to be stable so long as it gives scope to talent. Actually
name: it is the ability to give scope to the untalented that is most vital in maintaining social stability. For not only are the untalented more numerous but
extra: since they cannot transmute their grievances into a creative effort
column4: their disaffection will be more pronounced and explosive. Thus the most troublesome problem which confronts social engineering is how to provide for the untalented and
column6: how to provide against them. For there is a tendency in the untalented to divert their energies from their own development into the management
column8: and probably frustration of others. They want to police
column11: and meddle. In an adequate social order
column12: the untalented should be able to acquire a sense of usefulness and of growth without interfering with the development of talent around them. This requires
column14: an abundance of opportunities for purposeful action and self advancement. Secondly
column15: a wide diffusion of technical and social skills so that people will be able to work and manage their affairs with a minimum of tutelage. The scribe mentality is best neutralized by canalizing energies into purposeful and useful pursuits
column16: and by raising the cultural level of the whole population so as to blur the dividing line between the educated and the uneducated. If such an arrangement lacks provisions for the encouragement of the talented it yet has the merit of not interfering with them.|
column19: Writer

content: |One should see the dominant role of the weak in shaping man's fate not as a perversion of natural instincts and vital impulses
name: but as the starting point of the deviation which led man to break away from
column4: nature — not as degeneration but as the generation of a new order of creation.The corruption inherent in absolute power derives from the fact that such power is never free from the tendency to turn man into a thing
column5: and press him back into the matrix of nature from which he has risen. For the impulse of power is to turn every variable into a constant
column6: and give to commands the inexorableness and relentlessness of laws of nature. Hence absolute power corrupts even when exercised for humane purposes. The benevolent despot who sees himself as a shepherd of the people still demands from others the submissiveness of sheep. The taint inherent in absolute power is not its inhumanity but its anti-humanity.|

content: |The weak are not a noble breed. Their sublime deeds of faith
name: daring
extra: and self-sacrifice usually spring from questionable motives. The weak hate not wickedness but weakness; and one instance of their hatred of weakness is hatred of self. All the passionate pursuits of the weak are in some degree a striving to escape
column5: or disguise an unwanted self. It is a striving shot through with malice
column8: and a host of petty impulses; yet it often culminates in superb achievements. Thus we find that people who fail in everyday affairs often show a tendency to reach out for the impossible. They become responsive to grandiose schemes
column10: formidable energies and a special fitness in the performance of tasks which would stump superior people. It seems paradoxical that defeat in dealing with the possible should embolden people to attempt the impossible
column11: but a familiarity with the mentality of the weak reveals that what seems a path of daring is actually an easy way out: It is to escape the responsibility for failure that the weak so eagerly throw themselves into grandiose undertakings. For when we fail in attaining the possible the blame is solely ours
column12: but when we fail in attaining the impossible we are justified in attributing it to the magnitude of the task.|

content: |To dispose a soul to action we must upset its equilibrium. page 27
name: Buccaneer Books edition (1990) ISBN 0899667481 172 pages total|

content: |There can be no freedom without freedom to fail. page 80
name: Buccaneer Books edition (1990) ISBN 0899667481 172 pages total|

content: The ratio between supervisory and producing personnel is always highest where the intellectuals are in power. In a Communist country it takes half the population to supervise the other half.
name: Eric Hoffer

content: |One would like to see mankind spend the balance of the century in a total effort to clean up and groom the surface of the globe — wipe out the jungles
name: turn deserts and swamps into arable land
column7: and make the whole land mass a fit habitation for Man. The globe should be our and not nature's home
column8: and we no longer nature's guests.|

content: |Free men are aware of the imperfection inherent in human affairs
name: and they are willing to fight and die for that which is not perfect. They know that basic human problems can have no final solutions
column7: and that the good life is compounded of half measures
column10: and gropings toward the perfect. The rejection of approximations and the insistence on absolutes are the manifestation of a nihilism that loathes freedom

content: |Up to now
name: America has not been a good milieu for the rise of a mass movement. What starts out here as a mass movement ends up as a racket
column6: |Frequently misquoted as "Every great cause begins as a movement
column8: and eventually degenerates into a racket."|

content: |The attitude of the intellectual community toward America is shaped not by the creative few but by the many who for one reason or another cannot transmute their dissatisfaction into a creative impulse
name: and cannot acquire a sense of uniqueness and of growth by developing and expressing their capacities and talents. There is nothing in contemporary America that can cure or alleviate their chronic frustration. They want power
column4: and opportunities for imposing action. Even if we should banish poverty from the land
column5: lift up the Negro to true equality
column7: and give half of the national income as foreign aid
column8: they will still see America as an air-conditioned nightmare unfit for them to live in.|

content: |The Jews are a peculiar people: things permitted to other nations are forbidden to the Jews. Other nations drive out thousands
name: even millions of people and there is no refugee problem. Russia did it
column4: Turkey threw out a million Greeks
column5: and Algeria a million Frenchman. Indonesia threw out heaven knows how many Chinese — and no one says a word about refugees.But in the case of Israel the displaced Arabs have become eternal refugees. Everyone insists that Israel must take back every single Arab.Arnold Toynbee calls the displacement of the Arabs an atrocity greater than any committed by the Nazis. Other nations when victorious on the battlefield dictate peace terms. But when Israel is victorious it must sue for peace.|

content: |Everyone expects the Jews to be the only real Christians in this world. Other nations when they are defeated survive and recover but should Israel be defeated it would be destroyed. Had Nasser triumphed last June he would have wiped Israel off the map
name: and no one would have lifted a finger to save the Jews. No commitment to the Jews by any government
column4: is worth the paper it is written on.There is a cry of outrage all over the world when people die in Vietnam or when two Negroes are executed in Rhodesia. But when Hitler slaughtered Jews no one remonstrated with him. The Swedes
column5: who are ready to break off diplomatic relations with America because of what we do in Vietnam
column6: did not let out a peep when Hitler was slaughtering Jews.They sent Hitler choice iron ore
column8: and serviced his troop trains to Norway.|

content: Yet at this moment Israel is our only reliable and unconditional ally. We can rely more on Israel than Israel can rely on us. And one has only to imagine what would have happened last summer had the Arabs and their Russian backers won the war to realize how vital the survival of Israel is to America and the West in general.
name: Eric Hoffer

content: You accept certain unlovely things about yourself and manage to live with them. The atonement for such an acceptance is that you make allowances for others — that you cleanse yourself of the sin of self-righteousness.
name: Eric Hoffer

content: |There is
name: for instance
extra: the fact that there is a greater readiness to work in a society with a high standard of living than in one with a low standard. We are more ready to strive and work for superfluities than for necessities. People who are clear-sighted
column5: and sober-minded will not go on working once their reasonable needs are satisfied. A society that refuses to strive for superfluities is likely to end up lacking in necessities. The readiness to work springs from trivial
column6: questionable motives. … A vigorous society is a society made up of people who set their hearts on toys
column7: and who would work for superfluities than for necessities. The self-righteous moralists decry such a society
column8: yet it is well to keep in mind that both children and artists need luxuries more than they need necessities.|

content: |The significant point is that people unfit for freedom — who cannot do much with it — are hungry for power. The desire for freedom is an attribute of a "have" type of self. It says: leave me alone and I shall grow
name: learn
extra: and realize my capacities. The desire for power is basically an attribute of a "have-not" type of self. If Hitler had had the talents and the temperament of a genuine artist
column4: if Stalin had had the capacity to become a first-rate theoretician
column5: if Napoleon had had the makings of a great poet or philosopher they would hardly have developed the all-consuming lust for absolute power.Freedom gives us a chance to realize our human and individual uniqueness. Absolute power can also bestow uniqueness: to have absolute power is to have the power to reduce all the people around us to puppets
column9: and be the only man in sight. Absolute power achieves uniqueness by dehumanizing others.To sum up: Those who lack the capacity to achieve much in an atmosphere of freedom will clamor for power.|

content: |A just society must strive with all its might to right wrongs even if righting wrongs is a highly perilous undertaking. But if it is to survive
name: a just society must be strong and resolute enough to deal swiftly and relentlessly with those who would mistake its good will for weakness.|

content: |When cowardice becomes a fashion its adherents are without number
name: and it masquerades as forbearance

content: |Social stability is the product of an equilibrium between a vigorous majority and violent minorities. Disorder does not come from an increased inner pressure or from the interaction of explosive ingredients. There is no reason to believe that the nature of the violent minorities is now greatly different from what it was in the past. What has changed is the will and ability of the majority to react.It is hard to tell what causes the pervasive timidity. One thinks of video-induced stupor
name: intake of tranquilizers
extra: fear of not living to enjoy the many new possessions and toys
column4: the example of our betters in cities and on campuses who high-mindedly surrender to threats of violence and make cowardice fashionable.|

content: Good and evil grow up together and are bound in an equilibrium that cannot be sundered. The most we can do is try to tilt the equilibrium toward the good.
name: Eric Hoffer

content: |Man is a luxury-loving animal. Take away play
name: fancies
column4: and you will turn man into a dull
column6: barely energetic enough to obtain a bare subsistence. A society becomes stagnant when its people are too rational or too serious to be tempted by baubles.|

content: The Savior who wants to turn men into angels is as much a hater of human nature as the totalitarian despot who wants to turn them into puppets.There are similarities between absolute power and absolute faith: a demand for absolute obedience; a readiness to attempt the impossible; a bias for simple solutions — to cut the knot rather than unravel it; the viewing of compromise as surrender; the tendency to manipulate people and "experiment with blood."Both absolute power and absolute faith are instruments of dehumanization. Hence absolute faith corrupts as absolutely as absolute power.
name: Eric Hoffer
extra: Section 13; often the final portion of this is quoted alone as: "Absolute faith corrupts as absolutely as absolute power."

content: |The central task of education is to implant a will and a facility for learning; it should produce not learned but learning people. The truly human society is a learning society
name: where grandparents
column4: and children are students together.In a time of drastic change it is the learners who inherit the future. The learned usually find themselves equipped to live in a world that no longer exists.|

content: It is the malady of our age that the young are so busy teaching us that they have no time left to learn.
name: Eric Hoffer

content: |Commitment becomes hysterical when those who have nothing to give advocate generosity
name: and those who have nothing to give up preach renunciation.|

content: Nature has no compassion. Nature accepts no excuses and the only punishment it knows is death.
name: Eric Hoffer

content: An empty head is not really empty; it is stuffed with rubbish. Hence the difficulty of forcing anything into an empty head.
name: Eric Hoffer

content: It is a talent of the weak to persuade themselves that they suffer for something when they suffer from something; that they are showing the way when they are running away; that they see the light when they feel the heat; that they are chosen when they are shunned.
name: Eric Hoffer

content: Nonconformists travel as a rule in bunches. You rarely find a nonconformist who goes it alone. And woe to him inside a nonconformist clique who does not conform with nonconformity.
name: Eric Hoffer

content: The history of this country was made largely by people who wanted to be left alone. Those who could not thrive when left to themselves never felt at ease in America.
name: Eric Hoffer

content: We take for granted the need to escape the self. Yet the self can also be a refuge. In totalitarian countries the great hunger is for private life. Absorption in the minutiae of an individual existence is the only refuge from the apocalyptic madhouse staged by maniacal saviors of humanity.
name: Eric Hoffer

content: |One wonders whether a generation that demands instant satisfaction of all its needs and instant solution of the world's problems will produce anything of lasting value. Such a generation
name: even when equipped with the most modern technology
extra: will be essentially primitive — it will stand in awe of nature
column4: and submit to the tutelage of medicine men.|

content: |They who lack talent expect things to happen without effort. They ascribe failure to a lack of inspiration or ability
name: or to misfortune
extra: rather than to insufficient application. At the core of every true talent there is an awareness of the difficulties inherent in any achievement
column4: and the confidence that by persistence and patience something worthwhile will be realized. Thus talent is a species of vigor.|

content: What monstrosities would walk the streets were some people's faces as unfinished as their minds.
name: Eric Hoffer

content: |The ignorant are a reservoir of daring. It almost seems that those who have yet to discover the known are particularly equipped for dealing with the unknown. The unlearned have often rushed in where the learned feared to tread
name: and it is the credulous who are tempted to attempt the impossible. They know not whither they are going

content: To the excessively fearful the chief characteristic of power is its arbitrariness. Man had to gain enormously in confidence before he could conceive an all-powerful God who obeys his own laws.
name: Eric Hoffer

content: The hardest arithmetic to master is that which enables us to count our blessings.
name: Eric Hoffer

content: Our greatest weariness comes from work not done.
name: Eric Hoffer

content: |It is the individual only who is timeless. Societies
name: cultures
extra: and civilizations — past and present — are often incomprehensible to outsiders
column7: and preoccupations have remained unchanged through the millennia. Thus
column8: we are up against the paradox that the individual who is more complex
column10: and mysterious than any communal entity is the one nearest to our understanding; so near that even the interval of millennia cannot weaken our feeling of kinship. If in some manner the voice of an individual reaches us from the remotest distance of time
column11: it is a timeless voice speaking about ourselves.|

content: |Both the revolutionary and the creative individual are perpetual juveniles. The revolutionary does not grow up because he cannot grow
name: while the creative individual cannot grow up because he keeps growing.|

content: A war is not won if the defeated enemy has not been turned into a friend.
name: Eric Hoffer

content: That which is unique and worthwhile in us makes itself felt only in flashes. If we do not know how to catch and savor the flashes we are without growth and exhilaration.
name: Eric Hoffer
extra: Also quoted in Between the Devil and the Dragon : The Best Essays and Aphorisms of Eric Hoffer (1982)

content: |The monstrous evils of the twentieth century have shown us that the greediest money grubbers are gentle doves compared with money-hating wolves like Lenin
name: Stalin
column4: who in less than three decades killed or maimed nearly a hundred million men
column6: and children and brought untold suffering to a large portion of mankind.|

content: |Ours is a golden age of minorities. At no time in the past have dissident minorities felt so much at home and had so much room to throw their weight around. They speak and act as if they were "the people
name: and what they abominate most is the dissent of the majority.|,Eric Hoffer,|The Trend Toward Anarchy
extra:
p. 52|
|The best education will not immunize a person against corruption by power. The best education does not automatically make people compassionate. We know this more clearly than any preceding generation. Our time has seen the best-educated society, situated in the heart of the most civilized part of the world, give birth to the most murderously vengeful government in history.Forty years ago the philosopher Alfred North Whitehead thought it self-evident that you would get a good government if you took power out of the hands of the acquisitive and gave it to the learned and the cultivated. At present, a child in kindergarten knows better than that.|,Eric Hoffer,p. 40-41
|I hang onto my prejudices, they are the testicles of my mind.|,Eric Hoffer,p. 79
|The Renaissance was a time of mercenary soldiers, ours is a time of mercenary labor.|,Eric Hoffer, 
|To think out a problem is not unlike drawing a caricature. You have to exaggerate the salient point and leave out that which is not typical. To illustrate a principle
column4: says Bagehot, you must exaggerate much and you must omit much." As to the quantity of absolute truth in a thought: it seems to me the more comprehensive and unobjectionable a thought becomes
column5: the more clumsy and unexciting it gets. I like half-truths of a certain kind — they are interesting and they stimulate.|

content: There is no reason why the profoundest thoughts should not make easy and exciting reading. A profound thought is an exciting thing — as exciting as a detective's deductions or hunches. The simpler the words in which a thought is expressed the more stimulating its effect.
name: Eric Hoffer

content: |Perhaps people throw themselves into heated polemics to give content to their lives
name: to warm their hearts. What Luther said of hatred is true of all quarreling. There is nothing like a feud to make life seem full and interesting.|

content: It is not good for our efforts at self-realization to know the opinions other people have of us. It is difficult or perhaps impossible to be ourselves if we are known.
name: Eric Hoffer

content: What merit there is in my thinking is derived from two peculiarities: (1) My inability to be familiar with anything. I simply can't take things for granted. (2) My endless patience. I assume that the only way to find an answer is to hang on long enough and keep groping.
name: Eric Hoffer

content: I am more and more convinced that taking life over-seriously is a frivolous thing. There is an affected self-dramatizing in the brooding over one's prospects and destiny. The trifling attitude of an Ecclesiastes is essentially sober and serious. It is in closer touch with the so-called eternal truths than are the most penetrating metaphysical probing and the most sensitive poetic insights.
name: Eric Hoffer

content: This food-and-shelter theory concerning man's efforts is without insight. Our most persistent and spectacular efforts are concerned not with the preservation of what we are but with the building up of an imaginary conception of ourselves in the opinion of others. The desire for praise is more imperative than the desire for food and shelter.
name: Eric Hoffer

content: |The chief difference between me and others is that I have plenty of time — not only because I am without a multitude of responsibilities and without daily tasks
name: which demand attention: But also because I am basically without ambition. Neither the present nor the future has claims on me.|

content: |The sense of worth derived from creative work depends upon "recognition" by others
name: which is never automatic. As a result
column4: even when it is the only open one
column5: is taken with reluctance. Men of talent have to be goaded to engage in creative work. The groans and laments of even the most gifted and prolific echo through the ages.|

content: |Thinking with me is like looking for a person whose address I don't know. I stand on a street corner all day long waiting for him to pass by. Certainly there are more efficient ways of locating a person whose address you don't know. But if you have a whole lifetime to wait and enjoy watching things go by
name: then waiting on street corners is as good a method as any. If you don't find the person you are looking for

content: |To think for oneself is not only
name: as Gide said

content: |By circumstance and perhaps also by inclination
name: I think in complete intellectual isolation. To expect others to help me think seems to me almost like expecting them to help me digest my food.|

content: |The most important point is — and remains — not to take oneself seriously. There is no past
name: and
column4: no future. There are but a few years — ten at the most. You pass your days as best you can
column5: doing as little harm as possible. Let the desires be few and treat expectations as weeds. You read
column6: scribble as the spirit moves you
column8: see every week the few people you are attached to. Again: guard yourself

content: |It is precisely because we can never really know ourselves
name: but only guess
extra: that we are so vehement about the good and the evil ascribed to us by others. In maintaining ourselves against all comers
column4: we are maintaining something that is unknown
column6: and never wholly provable. We need a chorus of consent
column7: and we are engaged in an unceasing proselytizing campaign in our own behalf.|

content: |How terribly hard and almost impossible it is to tell the truth. More than anything else
name: the artist in us prevents us from telling aught as it really happened. We deal with the truth as the cook deals with meat and vegetables.|

content: |In products of the human mind
name: simplicity marks the end of a process of refining
extra: while complexity marks a primitive stage. Michelangelo's definition of art as the purgation of superfluities suggests that the creative effort consists largely in the elimination of that which complicates and confuses a pattern|

content: |A multitude of words is probably the most formidable means of blurring and obscuring thought. There is no thought
name: however momentous
extra: that cannot be expressed lucidly in 200 words.|

content: |It is the Frenchman's readiness to exaggerate that is at the root of his intellectual lucidity and also of his capacity for acknowledging merit. The English were not afraid to exaggerate in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries
name: and they were then not far behind the French in the lucidity of their thinking.... There is hardly a single instance of cultural vigor marked by moderation in expression.|

content: It has been my experience that there is no substitute for time where thinking is concerned. Why is it so? The answer seems to be that in many cases to think means to be able to allow the mind to stray from the task at hand. The mind must be able to be "elsewhere." This needs time.
name: Eric Hoffer

content: Our doubts about ourselves cannot be banished except by working at that which is the one and only thing we know we ought to do. Other people's assertions cannot silence the howling dirge within us. It is our talents rusting unused within us that secrete the poison of self-doubt into our bloodstream.
name: Eric Hoffer

content: |We are ready to die for an opinion but not for a fact: indeed
name: it is by our readiness to die that we try to prove the factualness of our opinion.|

content: |The impulse to think
name: to philosophize and spin beauty and brilliance out of mind and soul
extra: is somehow the offspring of resistance — of an effort to overcome an apparently insurmountable obstacle. Hence cultural creativeness is more likely to flourish in an atmosphere of restriction
column4: of an imposed pattern of thought and behavior
column5: than in one of total freedom.|

content: |One is not quite certain that creativeness in the arts
name: literature
extra: and science functions best in an environment of absolute freedom. Chances are that a relatively mild tyranny stimulates creativeness.|

content: |Actual creativeness is a matter of moments. One has to piece together the minute grains to make a lump. And it is so easy to miss the momentary flashes
name: it is like sluicing in placer mining. He who lets the flakes float by has nothing to show for his trouble.|

content: |Universities are an example of organizations dominated wholly by intellectuals; yet
name: outside pure science
extra: they have not been an optimal milieu for the unfolding of creative talents. In neither art
column7: nor planning have the Universities figured as originators or as seedbeds of new talents and energies.|

content: |It is apparently vital that we should be in the dark about ourselves — not to be clear about our intentions
name: fears
extra: and hopes. There is a stubborn effort in us to set up a compact screen between consciousness and the self.|

content: To overestimate the originality of one's thoughts is perhaps a less serious defect than being unaware of their newness. There is a more pronounced lack of sensitivity in underestimating (ourselves and others) than in overestimating.
name: Eric Hoffer

content: |Good writing
name: like gold
extra: combines lustrous lucidity with high density. What this means is good writing is packed with hints.|

content: |I have never felt that I had a thought too profound for others to understand. On the contrary
name: it always seemed to me axiomatic that what was clear to me should be clear and easy to everyone else. This despite the fact that it often took me years to grope my way to an idea.... I can spend days and even months on a single sentence. I do not know how to skip. To think and write with me is like putting brick on brick.|

content: |How rare it is to come across a piece of writing that is unambiguous
name: unqualified
extra: and also unblurred by understatements or subtleties
column4: and yet at the same time urbane and tolerant. It is a vice of the scientific method when applied to human affairs that it fosters hemming and hawing and a scrupulousness that easily degenerates into obscurity and meaninglessness.|

content: Flaubert and Nietzsche have emphasized the importance of standing up and walking in the process of thinking. The peripatetics were perhaps motivated by the same awareness. Yet purposeful walking — what we call marching — is an enemy of thought and is used as a powerful instrument for the suppression of independent thought and the inculcation of unquestioned obedience.
name: Eric Hoffer

content: Total innovation is a flight from comparison and also from imitation. Those who discover things for themselves and express them in their own way are not overly bothered by the fact that others have already discovered these things — have even discovered them over and over again — and have expressed what they found in all manner of ways.
name: Eric Hoffer

content: |What counts most is holding on. The growth of a train of thought is not a direct forward flow. There is a succession of spurts separated by intervals of stagnation
name: frustration
extra: and discouragement. If you hold on
column4: there is bound to come a certain clarification. The unessential components drop off and a coherent
column5: lucid whole begins to take shape.|

content: Originality is not something continuous but something intermittent — a flash of the briefest duration. One must have the time and be watchful (be attuned) to catch the flash and fix it. One must know how to catch and preserve these scant flakes of gold sluiced out of the sand and rocks of everyday life. Originality does not come nugget-size.
name: Eric Hoffer

content: A good sentence is a key. It unlocks the mind of the reader.
name: Eric Hoffer

content: As a full-time longshoreman I am necessarily more a scribbler than a writer. But I am also so by inclination. The writing I can enjoy is the sketching of an idea in a few dozen words — two hundred at most. Elaboration and expansion are for me hard going. An article of several thousand words becomes inevitably a mosaic of ideas — a series of ideas stuck together.
name: Eric Hoffer

content: Some people have no original ideas because they do not think well enough of themselves to consider their ideas worth noticing and developing.
name: Eric Hoffer

content: |Disraeli felt that "nothing could compensate his obscure youth
name: not even a glorious old age." Practically all writers and artists are aware of their destiny and see themselves as actors in a fateful drama. With me
column5: fateful coincidences — nothing really matters. I have written a number of good sentences. I have kept free of delusions. I know I am going to die soon.|

content: |I could never figure out — or probably did not take the trouble to figure out — what the great philosophical problems are about. The momentous statements I come across are at best a storm in a teacup. There are quite a number of people who have a vested interest in the stuff
name: make a noble living out of it
extra: and they conspire with one another to keep it alive.|

content: |In all my life I never competed for fortune
name: for a woman
extra: or for fame. I learned to write in total isolation. My first work was also my best
column4: and the first thing published. I never belonged to a circle or clique. I did not know I was writing a book until it was written. When my first book was published there was no one near me
column5: an acquaintance let alone a friend
column6: to congratulate me. I have never savored triumph

content: |The world's a fine place for those who go out to take it; there's lots of unknown stuff in it yet. I'll fill your lap
name: my pretty
extra: so full of treasures that you shan't know yourself. A man wasn't meant to sit at home...|

content: |The Forsytes were resentful of something
name: not individually
extra: but as a family; this resentment expressed itself in an added perfection of raiment
column6: and — the sniff. Danger — so indispensable in bringing out the fundamental quality of any society

content: |In the development of the great series of animal organisms
name: the Nervous System assumes more and more of an imperial character. The rank held by any animal is determined by this character
extra: and not at all by its bulk
column5: or even its utility. In like manner
column6: in the development of the social organism
column7: as the life of nations becomes more complex
column8: Thought assumes a more imperial character; and Literature
column10: becomes a delicate index of social evolution. Barbarous societies show only the germs of literary life. But advancing civilisation
column11: bringing with it increased conquest over material agencies
column12: disengages the mind from the pressure of immediate wants
column13: and the loosened energy finds in leisure both the demand and the means of a new activity: the demand
column14: because long unoccupied hours have to be rescued from the weariness of inaction; the means
column15: because this call upon the energies nourishes a greater ambition and furnishes a wider arena.|

content: |Literature is at once the cause and the effect of social progress. It deepens our natural sensibilities
name: and strengthens by exercise our intellectual capacities. It stores up the accumulated experience of the race
extra: connecting Past and Present into a conscious unity; and with this store it feeds successive generations
column4: to be fed in turn by them. As its importance emerges into more general recognition
column5: it necessarily draws after it a larger crowd of servitors
column6: filling noble minds with a noble ambition.|

content: |In Science the paramount appeal is to the Intellect — its purpose being instruction; in Art
name: the paramount appeal is to the Emotions — its purpose being pleasure. A work of Art must of course indirectly appeal to the Intellect
extra: and a work of Science will also indirectly appeal to the Feelings; nevertheless a poem on the stars and a treatise on astronomy have distinct aims and distinct methods. But having recognised the broadly-marked differences
column4: we are called upon to ascertain the underlying resemblances. Logic and Imagination belong equally to both. It is only because men have been attracted by the differences that they have overlooked the not less important affinities.|

content: |Every one who has seriously investigated a novel question
name: who has really interrogated Nature with a view to a distinct answer
extra: will bear me out in saying that it requires intense and sustained effort of imagination. The relations of sequence among the phenomena must be seen; they are hidden; they can only be seen mentally; a thousand suggestions rise before the mind
column4: but they are recognised as old suggestions
column5: or as inadequate to reveal what is sought; the experiments by which the problem may be solved have to be imagined; and to imagine a good experiment is as difficult as to invent a good fable
column6: for we must have distinctly present — clear mental vision — the known qualities and relations of all the objects
column7: and must see what will be the effect of introducing some new qualifying agent. If any one thinks this is easy
column8: let him try it: the trial will teach him a lesson respecting the methods of intellectual activity not without its use.|

content: |The discoverer and the poet are inventors; and they are so because their mental vision detects the unapparent
name: unsuspected facts
extra: almost as vividly as ocular vision rests on the apparent and familiar.|

content: |Philosophy and Art both render the invisible visible by imagination. Where Sense observes two isolated objects
name: Imagination discloses two related objects. This relation is the nexus visible. We had not seen it before; it is apparent now. Where we should only see a calamity the poet makes us see a tragedy. Where we could only see a sunrise he enables us to see|

content: A work is imaginative in virtue of the power of its images over our emotions; not in virtue of any rarity or surprisingness in the images themselves.
name: George Henry Lewes

content: |Foolish critics often betray their ignorance by saying that a painter or a writer "only copies what he has seen
name: or puts down what he has known." They forget that no man imagines what he has not seen or known
extra: and that it is in the selection of the characteristic details that the artistic power is manifested.|

content: |I wish to call special attention to the psychological fact
name: that fairies and demons
extra: remote as they are from experience
column4: are not created by a more vigorous effort of imagination than milk maids and poachers. The intensity of vision in the artist and of vividness in his creations are the sole tests of his imaginative power.|

content: |An artist produces an effect in virtue of the distinctness with which he sees the objects he represents
name: seeing them not vaguely as in vanishing apparitions
column4: and in their most characteristic relations. To this Vision he adds artistic skill with which to make us see. He may have clear conceptions
column5: yet fail to make them clear to us: in this case he has imagination
column6: but is not an artist. Without clear Vision no skill can avail. Imperfect Vision necessitates imperfect representation; words take the place of ideas.|

content: |If clear Vision be indispensable to success in Art
name: all means of securing that clearness should be sought. Now one means is that of detaining an image long enough before the mind to allow of its being seen in all its characteristics. The explanation Newton gave of his discovery of the great law
extra: points in this direction; it was by always thinking of the subject
column4: by keeping it constantly before his mind
column5: that he finally saw the truth. Artists brood over the chaos of their suggestions
column6: and thus shape them into creations.|

content: |Minds differ in the vividness with which they recall the elements of previous experience
name: and mentally see the absent objects; they differ also in the aptitudes for selection
column4: and recombination: the fine selective instinct of the artist
column5: which makes him fasten upon the details which will most powerfully affect us
column6: without any disturbance of the harmony of the general impression
column7: does not depend solely upon the vividness of his memory and the clearness with which the objects are seen
column8: but depends also upon very complex and peculiar conditions of sympathy which we call genius.|

content: |Our native susceptibilities and acquired tastes determine which of the many qualities in an object shall most impress us
name: and be most clearly recalled. One man remembers the combustible properties of a substance
extra: which to another is memorable for its polarising property; to one man a stream is so much water-power
column4: to another a rendezveus for lovers.|

content: |Genius is rarely able to give any account of its own processes. But those who have had ample opportunities of intimately knowing the growth of works in the minds of artists
name: will bear me out in saying that a vivid memory supplies the elements from a thousand different sources
extra: most of which are quite beyond the power of localisation
column4: the experience of yesterday being strangely intermingled with the dim suggestions of early years
column5: the tones heard in childhood sounding through the diapason of sorrowing maturity; and all these kaleidoscopic fragments are recomposed into images that seem to have a corresponding reality of their own.|

content: |I wish to guard the Principle of Vision from certain misconceptions which might arise on a simple statement of it. The principle insists on the artist assuring himself that he distinctly sees what he attempts to represent. What he sees
name: and how he represents it
extra: depend on other principles. To make even this principle of Vision thoroughly intelligible in its application to all forms of Literature and Art
column4: it must be considered in connection with the two other principles — Sincerity and Beauty
column5: which are involved in all successful works.|

content: It is always understood as an expression of condemnation when anything in Literature or Art is said to be done for effect; and yet to produce an effect is the aim and end of both.

content: |It is impossible to deny that dishonest men often grow rich and famous
name: becoming powerful in their parish or in parliament. Their portraits simper from shop windows; and they live and die respected. This success is theirs; yet it is not the success which a noble soul will envy. Apart from the risk of discovery and infamy
extra: there is the certainty of a conscience ill at ease
column6: so given over to lower lusts
column7: that a healthy instinct recoils from such a state. Observe
column9: that in Literature the possible rewards of dishonesty are small
column10: and the probability of detection great. In Life a dishonest man is chiefly moved by desires towards some tangible result of money or power; if he get these he has got all. The man of letters has a higher aim: the very object of his toil is to secure the sympathy and respect of men; and the rewards of his toil may be paid in money
column12: or consciousness of earnest effort. The first of these may sometimes be gained without Sincerity. Fame may also
column14: be erected on an unstable ground
column15: though it will inevitably be destroyed again. But the last and not least reward is to be gained by every one without fear of failure
column16: without risk of change. Sincere work is good work
column17: be it never so humble; and sincere work is not only an indestructible delight to the worker by its very genuineness
column18: but is immortal in the best sense
column19: for it lives for ever in its influence. There is no good Dictionary

name: colouring or suppressing facts with a conscious purpose; and writers who never stole an idea nor pretended to honours for which they had not striven

column6: Sincerity is nevertheless the only enduring strength.The principle is universal
column7: stretching from the highest purposes of Literature down to its smallest details. It underlies the labour of the philosopher
column14: and the compiler. It is visible in the publication of opinions

content: |A man must be himself convinced if he is to convince others. The prophet must be his own disciple
name: or he will make none. Enthusiasm is contagious: belief creates belief. There is no influence issuing from unbelief or from languid acquiescence. This is peculiarly noticeable in Art
extra: because Art depends on sympathy for its influence
column4: and unless the artist has felt the emotions he depicts we remain unmoved: in proportion to the depth of his feeling is our sympathetic response; in proportion to the shallowness or falsehood of his presentation is our coldness or indifference.|

content: |An orator whose purpose is to persuade men must speak the things they wish to hear; an orator
name: whose purpose is to move men
extra: must also avoid disturbing the emotional effect by any obtrusion of intellectual antagonism; but an author whose purpose is to instruct men
column5: must be careless of their opinions
column6: and think only of truth. It will often be a question when a man is or is not wise in advancing unpalateable opinions
column7: or in preaching heresies; but it can never be a question that a man should be silent if unprepared to speak the truth as he conceives it. Deference to popular opinion is one great source of bad writing
column8: and is all the more disastrous because the deference is paid to some purely hypothetical requirement. When a man fails to see the truth of certain generally accepted views
column9: there is no law compelling him to provoke animosity by announcing his dissent. He may be excused if he shrink from the lurid glory of martyrdom; he may be justified in not placing himself in a position of singularity. He may even be commended for not helping to perplex mankind with doubts which he feels to be founded on limited and possibly erroneous investigation. But if allegiance to truth lays no stern command upon him to speak out his immature dissent
column10: it does lay a stern command not to speak out hypocritical assent.|

content: There are many justifications of silence; there can be none of insincerity.

content: |I would not have the reader conclude that because I advocate plain-speaking even of unpopular views

extra: or express emotions they do not feel. And this rule is universal. Even truthful and modest men will sometimes violate the rule under the mistaken idea of being eloquent by means of the diction of eloquence. This is a source of bad Literature.|

content: |Sincerity is not only effective and honourable

content: |There are occasions when the simplest and fewest words surpass in effect all the wealth of rhetorical amplification. An example may be seen in the passage which has been a favourite illustration from the days of Longinus to our own. "God said: Let there be light! and there was light." This is a conception of power so calm and simple that it needs only to be presented in the fewest and the plainest words
name: and would be confused or weakened by any suggestion of accessories.|

content: |The first obligation of Simplicity is that of using the simplest means to secure the fullest effect. But although the mind instinctlvely rejects all needless complexity

content: |The selective instinct of the artist tells him when his language should be homely
name: and when it should be more elevated; and it is precisely in the imperceptible blending of the plain with the ornate that a great writer is distinguished. He uses the simplest phrases without triviality

content: |The definitions of humanism are many
name: but let us here take it to be the attitude of those men who think it an advantage to live in society
column5: in a complex and highly developed society
column6: and who believe that man fulfills his nature and reaches his proper stature in this circumstance. The personal virtues which humanism cherishes are intelligence
column8: and tolerance; the particular courage it asks for is that which is exercised in the support of these virtues. The qualities of intelligence which it chiefly prizes are modulation and flexibility.|

content: |The aspects of society that humanism most exalts are justice and continuity. That is why humanism is always being presented with a contradiction. For when it speaks of justice it holds that the human condition is absolute; yet when it speaks of continuity it implies that society is not absolute but pragmatic and even anomalous. Its intelligence dictates the removal of all that is anomalous; yet its ideal of social continuity is validated by by its perception that the effort to destroy anomaly out of hand will probably bring new and even worse anomalies
name: the nature of man being what it is. "Let justice be done though the heavens fall" is balanced by awareness that after the heavens fall justice will not ever be done again.|

content: Truth will do well enough if left to shift for herself. She seldom has received much aid from the power of great men to whom she is rarely known & seldom welcome. She has no need of force to procure entrance into the minds of men. Error indeed has often prevailed by the assistance of power or force. Truth is the proper & sufficient antagonist to error.
name: Thomas Jefferson
column4: published in The Writings of Thomas Jefferson : 1816–1826 (1899) edited by Paul Leicester Ford

content: |In the middle ages of Christianity opposition to the State opinions was hushed. The consequence was

content: |Compulsion in religion is distinguished peculiarly from compulsion in every other thing. I may grow rich by art I am compelled to follow
name: I may recover health by medicines I am compelled to take against my own judgment
extra: but I cannot be saved by a worship I disbelieve & abhor.|

content: |Locke denies toleration to those who entertain opinions contrary to those moral rules necessary for the preservation of society; as for instance
name: that faith is not to be kept with those of another persuasion
extra: … that dominion is founded in grace
column4: or who will not own & teach the duty of tolerating all men in matters of religion
column5: or who deny the existence of a god (it was a great thing to go so far—as he himself says of the parliament who framed the act of toleration … He says 'neither Pagan nor Mahomedan nor Jew ought to be excluded from the civil rights of the Commonwealth because of his religion.' Shall we suffer a Pagan to deal with us and not suffer him to pray to his god? Why have Christians been distinguished above all people who have ever lived
column6: for persecutions? Is it because it is the genius of their religion? No
column7: its genius is the reverse. It is the refusing toleration to those of a different opinion which has produced all the bustles and wars on account of religion. It was the misfortune of mankind that during the darker centuries the Christian priests following their ambition and avarice combining with the magistrate to divide the spoils of the people
column8: could establish the notion that schismatics might be ousted of their possessions & destroyed. This notion we have not yet cleared ourselves from.|

content: |Well aware that the opinions and belief of men depend not on their own will
name: but follow involuntarily the evidence proposed to their minds; that Almighty God hath created the mind free

column7: and are a departure from the plan of the holy author of our religion
column8: who being lord both of body and mind
column9: yet choose not to propagate it by coercions on either
column10: as was in his Almighty power to do
column11: but to exalt it by its influence on reason alone; that the impious presumption of legislature and ruler
column14: being themselves but fallible and uninspired men
column15: have assumed dominion over the faith of others
column16: setting up their own opinions and modes of thinking as the only true and infallible
column17: and as such endeavoring to impose them on others
column18: hath established and maintained false religions over the greatest part of the world and through all time: That to compel a man to furnish contributions of money for the propagation of opinions which he disbelieves and abhors
column19: is sinful and tyrannical; … that our civil rights have no dependence on our religious opinions
column20: any more than our opinions in physics or geometry; and therefore the proscribing any citizen as unworthy the public confidence by laying upon him an incapacity of being called to offices of trust or emolument

column24: he has a natural right; that it tends also to corrupt the principles of that very religion it is meant to encourage
column25: by bribing with a monopoly of worldly honours and emolumerits

column31: that truth is great and will prevail if left to herself; that she is the proper and sufficient antagonist to error

content: |History has informed us that bodies of men
name: as well as individuals
extra: are susceptible of the spirit of tyranny.|

content: |There are extraordinary situations which require extraordinary interposition. An exasperated people
name: who feel that they possess power
extra: are not easily restrained within limits strictly regular.|

content: |When the representative body have lost the confidence of their constituents
name: when they have notoriously made sale of their most valuable rights
extra: when they have assumed to themselves powers which the people never put into their hands
column4: then indeed their continuing in office becomes dangerous to the state
column5: and calls for an exercise of the power of dissolution.|

content: |From the nature of things
name: every society must at all times possess within itself the sovereign powers of legislation. The feelings of human nature revolt against the supposition of a state so situated as that it may not in any emergency provide against dangers which perhaps threaten immediate ruin. While those bodies are in existence to whom the people have delegated the powers of legislation
extra: they alone possess and may exercise those powers; but when they are dissolved by the lopping off one or more of their branches
column4: the power reverts to the people
column5: who may exercise it to unlimited extent
column8: or in any other way they may think proper.|

content: |From the nature and purpose of civil institutions
name: all the lands within the limits which any particular society has circumscribed around itself are assumed by that society
extra: and subject to their allotment only. This may be done by themselves
column6: to whom they may have delegated sovereign authority; and if they are alloted in neither of these ways
column7: each individual of the society may appropriate to himself such lands as he finds vacant
column8: and occupancy will give him title.|

content: |A free people [claim] their rights
name: as derived from the laws of nature
extra: and not as the gift of their chief magistrate.|

content: |Let those flatter who fear; it is not an American art. To give praise which is not due might be well from the venal

column5: not the proprietors of the people.|

content: |The God who gave us life gave us liberty at the same time; the hand of force may destroy

column5: and the pursuit of Happiness; that to secure these rights

content: |he has waged cruel war against human nature itself
name: violating it's most sacred rights of life & liberty in the persons of a distant people who never offended him

column4: or to incur miserable death in their transportation thither.  this piratical warfare
column5: the opprobrium of infidel powers; is the warfare of the Christian king of Great Britain. determined to keep open a market where MEN should be bought & sold he has prostituted his negative for suppressing every legislative attempt to prohibit or to restrain this execrable commerce: and that this assemblage of horrors might want no fact of distinguished die
column6: he is now exciting those very people to rise in arms among us

content: |Cultivators of the earth are the most valuable citizens. They are the most vigorous

content: |I am conscious that an equal division of property is impracticable. But the consequences of this enormous inequality producing so much misery to the bulk of mankind
name: legislators cannot invent too many devices for subdividing property..[a] means of silently lessening the inequality of property is to exempt all from taxation below a certain point
extra: and to tax the higher portions of property in geometrical progression as they rise.|

content: |Whenever there is in any country
name: uncultivated lands and unemployed poor
extra: it is clear that the laws of property have been so far extended as to violate natural right. The earth is given as a common stock for man to labour and live on.|

content: |It is an axiom in my mind
name: that our liberty can never be safe but in the hands of the people themselves
extra: and that too of the people with a certain degree of instruction. This it is the business of the State to effect

content: |What a stupendous
name: what an incomprehensible machine is man! Who can endure toil

column7: be deaf to all those motives whose powers supported him through his trial
column8: and inflict on his fellow men a bondage

|God forbid we should ever be twenty years without such a rebellion. The people cannot be all, and always, well informed. The part which is wrong will be discontented, in proportion to the importance of the facts they misconceive. If they remain quiet under such misconceptions, it is lethargy, the forerunner of death to the public liberty. … What country before ever existed a century and half without a rebellion? And what country can preserve its liberties if their rulers are not warned from time to time that their people preserve the spirit of resistance? Let them take arms. The remedy is to set them right as to facts, pardon and pacify them. What signify a few lives lost in a century or two? The tree of liberty must be refreshed from time to time with the blood of patriots and tyrants. It is its natural manure.|,Thomas Jefferson,|Letter to William Stephens Smith (13 November 1787), quoted in Padover's Jefferson On Democracy.|

Julian P. Boyd (1956), vol. 13, p. 269.|
